Award.AbstractNarration:
The grant provides funds to support the Bloomington Geometry Workshop. It is an annual meeting with the 2014 edition taking place over the weekend of April 26-27. The meeting starts with a Friday afternoon lecture and then there are seven to nine presentations on Saturday and Sunday by well-known active geometers primarily from the Midwestern region.

The Bloomington Geometry Workshop aims to promote scientific cooperation between geometers in Indiana and its neighboring states. Graduate student participation has continued to increase, and the organizers encourage this by asking speakers to make at least a portion of their talk accessible to graduate students. The Workshop organizers also invite at least one graduate student speaker and solicit graduate student participation from individual departments, especially from among under-represented groups.

More information about the workshop can be found on the website

http://www.math.indiana.edu/bgw/

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our goals for the 2014-2016 Bloomington Geometry Workshops were to establish research collaborations and connections between both emerging and established geometers from a variety of different universities within the Midwest region. We were especially interested in the training of graduate students and assisting young researchers in forming beneficial professional relationships. Another important purpose for the conference is the effective dissemination of recent important results in geometry to the wider community.

Our efforts to achieve these goals primarily included attracting area mathematicians and grad students through high quality lectures by the carefully chosen speakers together with numerous informal meetings and discussions afterwards and over meals. Each year, we include at least one very recent Ph.D. and at least one postdoctoral speaker among our other, generally quite renowned, speakers to invigorate participation and collaboration among the graduate students. We also reminded speakers of our desire to make the conference a beneficial experience for the graduate students and postdocs, and encouraged them to promote the conference in their own departments especially to their junior members. In the end, each conference was beneficial to all demographic strata.

Each year we also invite a world-renowned mathematician to be our headliner for the conference. In 2014 our headliner was Alex Eskin, in 2015 it was Benson Farb and in 2016, Danny Calegari. The complete list of our speakers each year can be found on our conference web site located here.

The 2014-2016 Workshops served between 40 and 50 registered participants including speakers. Of these, about 1/3rd were graduate students from other predominantly midwest universities and another
1/5th were graduate students from Indiana University. These numbers were augmented by additional undregistered faculty participants from the host institution, Indiana University.

Now having completed its 13th year, the Bloomington Geometry Workshop has grown to develop a regular following and function within the umbrella of mathematics research in the Midwest. This event has been recognized internationally and features prominently within the national scope of  conferences in the general areas of geometry, topology, and dynamical systems. It is our hope to continue this tradition into the future.
